accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist. When requesting audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact an RAC archivist for further instruction.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The National Committee on United States – China Relations (NCUSCR) was established in 1966 as a nonprofit educational organization with a mission to encourage mutual understanding and dialogue between citizens of the United States and China. The National Committee came into being through the cooperative efforts of scholars and civic, religious, and business leaders who, at a time of mutual hostility between the two countries, sought to stimulate public discussion about China and the United States' relations with it by sponsoring conferences, seminars, publications, and other education and outreach programs. In 1972, the National Committee sponsored the Chinese table tennis team's historic U. S. visit. This round of "Ping Pong Diplomacy," which followed closely on Richard Nixon's visit to China in February 1972, helped pave the way for later exchanges and, eventually, for the normalization of relations with China in 1979. Building on these cultural exchanges, the National Committee came to be a primary organizer of professional and policy exchanges between the two countries (and including Hong Kong and Taiwan), in the areas of foreign affairs and international relations, economic development, governance and legal affairs, education, mass media, environmental and global issues, etc. As its role in exchanges became more prominent, the National Committee turned over some of its educational programs to the Asia Society in the late 1970s, but it continues its educational role through public education events and ongoing outreach. Funding for the National Committee comes from the United States government (especially the Department of State), corporations, and foundations, as well as from its individual membership.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The National Committee on United States-China Relations donated its records to the Rockefeller Archive Center by deed of gift dated March 27, 2015.

processinfo.p: Special formats separated from the body of the collection are stored in the following containers:

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records of the National Committee on United States – China Relations are divided into ten record groups, which reflect the order in which the records were received (but which are otherwise an artificial distinction). The records are sorted intellectually into series, which carry over through all record groups, but they have received little or no physical rearrangement. RG 5 of the NCUSCR records is arranged into nine series: 2 – Exchanges - General; 3 – Exchanges to China; 4 – Exchanges from China; 5 – Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues; 6 – Publications and Reports; 8 – Programs, Projects, and Proposals; 10 – Development; 11 – Board of Directors, Committees, and Members records; and 15 – Clippings and Reference.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: RG 5 documents several of the NCUSCR's early projects and outreach programs in the late 1960s and early 1970s, including Curriculum Development and audiovisual projects, a China Trade Study, seminars for Young Business Leaders and other professionals, and its first National Convocation on the U. S. and China. Exchange materials include a collection of trip reports from early National Committee delegates to China as well as reports from other, non-affiliated exchange delegations. Later programs documented in RG 5 include the Ussuri Project collaboration in the 1990s, the Time Warner Internship Program, 1998-2006, and the visit of the China Fund for the Handicapped delegation in 1987.

RG 5 notably includes the full run of National Committee Board Minutes and Materials from 1966 to 2007. Other material of interest includes Foundation Correspondence - often grant related - in the Development series.

did.unittitle: Exchanges to China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Exchanges to China series in RG 5 contains collected trip reports from the first National Committee delegation trip to China in 1972-1973, and from academic and civic leaders who participated in the University Presidents and World Affairs delegations in 1974 and 1975. Reports by individuals who traveled to China from 1973-1981, under the aegis of other organizations, complete the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Exchanges from China series in RG 5 documents the visit in October 1987 of the China Fund for the Handicapped delegation, headed by Deng Pufang (son of Deng Xiaoping), who was disabled after a fall from a window during the Cultural Revolution. Deng originally planned to visit in 1986, but he had to cancel his trip for health reasons. While it was a National Committee member who first broached the idea of a visit, other organizations – some with their own agendas – took interest in the project, which complicated the planning and created some conflicts.

did.unittitle: Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues series in RG 5 documents some of the National Committee's early public outreach programs, such as its seminars and briefings, 1967-1969, for Young Business Executives and Aerospace and Electronics Executives, and, especially, its First National Convocation, held in New York in March 1969. Viewed as an opportunity for fundraising as well as public educational outreach, the First National Convocation occasioned considerable press coverage, and an edited volume of papers, The United States and China: The Next Decade, was published in 1970. Finally, this series also includes proposals for follow-up symposia and records for "cooperative" (or jointly sponsored) symposia in 1971-1973, such as the Fund for Peace Convocation and a conference on China's Developmental Experience.

did.unittitle: Programs, Projects and Proposals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Programs, Projects, and Proposals series in RG 5 contains the records of four National Committee programs or projects: Curriculum Development, circa 1965-1975; its China Trade Study, 1966-1970; the Ussuri Project, circa 1992-2000; and the Time Warner Internship Program, 1998-2006.

The review and dissemination of educational and audiovisual resources on China for secondary and higher education was an early National Committee project. In 1968, the Committee produced its Critical Guide to Curriculum Units on China, and later sponsored publication of China: A Resource and Curriculum Guide, ed. Arlene Posner, in 1973 (with a revised edition in 1976). The records in this series relate to the creation of these guides, but particularly document the Committee's role as a clearinghouse for information and resources on China. In addition to the curriculum guides, the National Committee produced its China Conversations series of audiotaped interviews with various China specialists, which it then lent or distributed to schools and educational organizations and media outlets throughout the country.

The National Committee initiated a study of the issues surrounding trade with China in 1968, and in 1969 commissioned a three-part written report, published in 1970, on China Trade Prospects and U. S. Policy. The China Trade Study records in this series document the preparation and distribution of this report, as well as the corporate briefings held in San Francisco and New York in April 1970 to present and discuss the topic.

The Ussuri Project was a multiyear cooperative endeavor to establish sustainable land use and development policies for the Ussuri River Watershed, which traverses the borders of Far Eastern Russia and Heilongjiang Province in Northern China. Records dating mainly from 1992-1997 concern project background and planning, meetings, trip reports, agreements, exchange delegations, fundraising, and some follow-up.

The National Committee administered the Time Warner Internship Program from its start in 1998 through 2006. Designed for advanced undergraduate students in journalism or media studies from Fudan University, the program provided three-month internships at various Time Warner companies for three to six students a year. Records consist mainly of applications and internship reports.

did.unittitle: Time Warner Internship Program: SEVIS DS-3036 Exchange Program Application

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: NCUSCR application (form DS-3036) to the Department of State for designation as an exchange program sponsor (in relation to the Time Warner Internships). This designation would allow the NCUSCR to certify intern eligibility for J-1 (Exchange visitor) visas (which the YMCA International Program was handling on behalf of the National Committee). SEVIS (Student and Exchange Visitor Information Service) refers to the State Department's online monitoring system for exchange visitors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Development series in RG 5 notably includes a set of Foundation Correspondence files. In many cases, these Foundation files include grant applications, proposals, and reports, along with more routine correspondence or funding requests. Other materials include financial reporting and background literature. The series also includes a few individual alphabetical files, from an otherwise unidentified run of general correspondence, and more recent acknowledgements of contributions.

did.unittitle: Board of Directors, Committees, and Members records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Board of Directors, Committees, and Members records series in RG 5 contains the Board Minutes and Materials (mailings and memos) from its start in 1966 to 2007. Most of the files usefully include a detailed list of contents or divisions within the annual files. In addition to meeting minutes, materials include interim correspondence, nomination and membership lists, financial and audit reports, and frequently include cumulative lists of exchanges, as well as various trip or project reports.

Other records in the series include some early organizational and program planning files, as well as a reference file on the Committee of One Million, which opposed the admission of Red China to the United Nations. Finally, the series includes a set of files on former corporate members (1970s-1980s), and a few early membership files.
